stem: The nurse is evaluating clients with thyroid disorders. For each finding, select whether it is associated with Hypothyroidism (Hashimoto's) or Hyperthyroidism (Grave's Disease).

rows.text: Constipation, dry skin, and 'slug-like' mental status.

rationale.correct: Thyroid hormone (T3/T4) sets the body's metabolic 'speed.' (r1 & r4) Hypothyroidism 'slows' the body: weight gain, cold, constipation, and lethargy. (r2, r3, & r5) Hyperthyroidism 'speeds' up the body: high heart rate, heat intolerance, and the risk of thyroid storm. Exophthalmos is specific to Grave's disease (Hyper).
rationale.incorrect: Tachycardia is never an expected finding in hypothyroidism; bradycardia is the norm.
clinicalPearls: Levothyroxine is the drug of choice for hypothyroidism. It should be taken on an empty stomach in the morning.

mnemonic.title: U-P vs D-O-W-N
mnemonic.expansion: Hyper = Up (Temp, HR, Eyes). Hypo = Down (Metabolism, BP, Skin moisture).

reviewUnits.heading: Thyroid Imbalances
reviewUnits.body: Nurses monitor TSH and T4 levels. Diagnosis is usually autoimmune (Hashimoto's vs. Grave's). Priority nursing care for hyperthyroidism: Rest, cardiac monitoring, and cool environment.
